name: Relationship Communication - Conflict Avoidance
description: A 29-year-old whose conflict avoidance is damaging their marriage
demographics: 29-year-old male, married for 3 years, works as a software engineer, no children yet
presenting_issue: Avoids conflict with wife to the point of dishonesty, now facing serious relationship problems

change: Wife says she can't trust him anymore
Knows that hiding things makes problems worse
Hates the anxiety of keeping things from her
Wants to have kids but wife says not until this is resolved
Realizes his parents' marriage was full of secrets and doesn't want that
status_quo: Conflict feels unbearable - easier to just avoid it
When I try to bring things up, it always becomes a fight
She gets so upset, I can't handle seeing her that way
If I told her everything, she'd leave
Some things are better left unsaid

background: Grew up in a household where his father's anger was frightening and his mother's response was to avoid any conflict. Learned early that keeping quiet was safer. Met wife in college; she's more direct and has been frustrated by his avoidance from the start. Recently discovered he'd hidden a significant credit card debt because he was afraid to tell her. She's now questioning what else he might be hiding. They're in a crisis point where she's mentioned separation.
personality_notes: Gentle, conflict-averse, and eager to please. Genuinely loves his wife but has a deep fear of anger and abandonment. Uses 'white lies' and omissions as a protection strategy. Gets defensive when called dishonest because he doesn't see himself that way. Physical symptoms of anxiety during conflict - stomach problems, can't think clearly.
potential_change_talk_triggers: Exploring what kind of marriage he actually wants
Discussing what he learned from his parents' relationship
Talking about the difference between peace and the absence of conflict
Exploring the cost of his current approach
Discussing what trust means to him and to her
common_sustain_talk: I wasn't lying, I just didn't mention it
I was going to tell her when the time was right
Some people are just more private
I don't see why everything needs to be a discussion
opening_statement: So, my wife basically made me come here. She found out about some debt I hadn't told her about, and now she's acting like I'm some kind of pathological liar. I just... I didn't want to worry her. That's not the same as lying. But she doesn't see it that way, and now I'm here.
